text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 5.20.12, Abusive Tax Avoidance Transactions, Initial Contact and Research Actions Related to Abusive Tax Avoidance Transactions cases.
MATERIAL CHANGES
IRM 5.20.12.1, revised IRM subsection title and content to reﬂect internal control attributes. Added content to identify policy owner, program owner, program stakeholders and program goals.
content to identify policy owner, program owner, program stakeholders and program goals. IRM
through IRM
, added background information and content to identify authority, roles and responsibilities, measures, terms and acronyms, and related resources to internal control attributes. IRM
, updated the advance notice of potential third party contact requirements with the Taxpayer First Act. IRM
, revised this section to reﬂect the migration from
to CDW Knowledge Environment (CKGE). IRM
, a link to FATCA resources available on M
B/SE was added. IRM
, removed obsolete guidance on requesting Offshore Compliance Initiative Editorial corrections made throughout the IRM section.
Editorial corrections made throughout the IRM section.

This material supersedes IRM 5.20.12, dated 3-05-2015. Incorporates interim guidance memorandum titled, Interim Guidance on Third-Party Contact Notiﬁcation Procedures, control number SBSE-04-0719-0034 , dated July 26, 2019.
Initial Contact and Research Actions Related to Abusive Tax Avoidance Transactions cases 5.20.12 page 1
cases
) Purpose. This IRM provides guidance to Field Collection employees for contact and research actions related to Abusive Tax Avoidance Transaction (ATAT) cases. (
) Audience. The audience for this guidance is revenue officers in SB/SE Collection. (
) Policy Owner. Director, Collection Policy, SB/SE. (
) Program Owner. Collection Policy, SB/SE, Global Strategic Compliance, is program owner of this IRM. (
) Primary Stakeholders. The primary stakeholders are SB/SE Field and SB/SE Lead Development Center (LDC). (

) Program Goals. The goal of the Abusive Tax Avoidance Transactions collection program is to identify and effect tax administration on cases complex transactions or multiple/layered entities intended to make it difficult trace a taxpayer’s assets or sources of income. (

) Some abusive tax avoidance transactions (ATAT) encountered by revenue officers are designed to appear, and often are, quite complex and involve various transactions as well as numerous entities including trusts, corporations, limited liability companies and offshore entities. These transac- tions and multiple or layered entities are often used by a taxpayer to make it difficult to track and follow title to assets or locate income sources. (

) Research and investigation of ATAT cases does not entail techniques or unique to ATAT casework; however, some techniques are more commonly applied, such as use of the collection summons to follow income ﬂow or to determine nominees, and nominee/alter ego/transferee relationships title to assets. (
) Potential fraud indicators may be present in ATAT cases. Contact your local fraud enforcement advisor, when appropriate. (
) Research to identify the nature of the promotion or transaction used by a taxpayer is important in developing an effective case strategy for resolution ATAT cases. (
) Research prior to contact is essential in ATAT cases. Guidance on an initial analysis is located in IRM

, Taxpayer Contact. Additional research may be necessary due to the complexity of an ATAT case. the goal of ATAT schemes is often to disguise the taxpayer’s beneﬁcial ownership of assets, developing a complete and accurate ﬁnancial picture of taxpayer participating in an abusive scheme is especially important. It is important to have a full understanding of the scheme and the transactions taxpayer was involved with in order to maximize the effectiveness of any contacts. (
) Awareness of taxpayer rights is vitally important even in ATAT case work. Taxpayer rights, as identiﬁed in Pub
, Your Rights as a Taxpayer are addressed in IRM
, Collection Appeal Rights, and throughout IRM Part Internal Revenue Manual a # Only
Purpose. This IRM provides guidance to Field Collection employees for initial contact and research actions related to Abusive Tax Avoidance Transaction

Some abusive tax avoidance transactions (ATAT) encountered by revenue officers are designed to appear, and often are, quite complex and involve various transactions as well as numerous entities including trusts, corporations, limited liability companies and offshore entities. These transac- tions and multiple or layered entities are often used by a taxpayer to make it difficult to track and follow title to assets or locate income sources.
Abusive Tax Avoidance Transactions
The following authorities provide the basis for these guidelines:
The Director, Collection Policy is the executive responsible for the policies procedures to be employed by Field Collection personnel.
Field Collection group managers and territory managers are responsible for ensuring compliance with the guidance and procedures described in this
Management utilizes management information reports from the Inte
grated Collection System (ICS) and ENTITY systems to monitor and track timely and appropriate case actions. ICS contains unique case sub

codes to identify ATAT cases. The ENTITY database also contains queries to assist in the identiﬁcation of ATAT cases. Reports from the Embedded Quality Review System (EQRS) measure program consistency, effectiveness in case actions and compliance with policy and procedures. Trends from these reports are used to recommend improvements where necessary when errors are identiﬁed. Reports from EQRS provide management information used in guiding revenue officers to take timely, effective and appropriate case actions.

Collection Policy performs ATAT program reviews as necessary to verify compliance with IRM requirements and address Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA) and Government Accounting Office (GAO)audit ﬁndings.
Case reviews are performed by group managers and National Quality reviewers to ensure compliance with this IRM.
Operational reviews are performed by the territory manager and area director annually to evaluate program delivery and conformance to ad
ministrative and compliance requirements.
Field Collection managers perform program controls by performing case con- sultations, reviews, employee observations and security reviews. IRM

, Collection Group Manager, Territory Manager and Area Director Operational Aid, communicates responsibility for management to implement and monitor required internal controls. The Integrated Collection System, ENTITY Case Management System and Embedded Quality System provide management with case access and data to monitor internal controls.

) The initial contact time frames outlined in IRM

, Initial Contact Frames, apply to all Field Collection cases, including ATAT cases. However, the use of an appointment letter to initiate contact is common in ATAT work due to the complexity and other factors found more often in ATAT Issuing an appointment letter requesting the taxpayer provide the needed mation may provide for a more effective initial contact and allow the officer to determine the level of cooperation to expect from the taxpayer. Note: If a contact letter is used to initiate contact, a ﬁeld call to observe assets the lifestyle of the taxpayer is recommended.
The initial contact time frames outlined in IRM

, Initial Contact Time Frames, apply to all Field Collection cases, including ATAT cases. However, the use of an appointment letter to initiate contact is common in ATAT work due to the complexity and other factors found more often in ATAT inventories. Issuing an appointment letter requesting the taxpayer provide the needed infor- mation may provide for a more effective initial contact and allow the revenue officer to determine the level of cooperation to expect from the taxpayer.
Note: If a contact letter is used to initiate contact, a ﬁeld call to observe assets the lifestyle of the taxpayer is recommended.

In situations where the revenue officer determines the use of an appointment letter as the appropriate method for initiating contact with the taxpayer, the revenue officer will document the case history outlining the circumstances for Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

the determination. When creating the Integrated Collection System (ICS) history entry for the appointment letter contact, the revenue officer will select “Create History”, use Contact Type of “Correspondence”, select “Taxpayer Contact” and then “ATAT Appointment Letter.”

) When an appointment letter is used, the revenue officer will include Form

, Summary of Taxpayer Contact, listing the information and documents the taxpayer should bring to the scheduled appointment so that a complete ﬁnancial statement can be secured. Revenue officers should refrain from summons action until after it is determined that the taxpayer will not voluntarily provide the information being sought.
quirement for timely contact. (
) Prior to making contact, the revenue officer will need to: a. Verify that the taxpayer has been advised of potential third party as stated in IRM

). b. Identify the proper person to contact. Because ATAT cases often multiple entities and whipsaw assessments, care must be given to properly identify the contact person for each entity. Each whipsaw should be treated as an individual entity unless the key taxpayer the Individual Master File (IMF) taxpayer) has now reported all income their tax return. (
) When the entity is a trust, the initial contact letter can be used to also a copy of Form
, Notice Concerning Fiduciary Relationship. This is necessary to determine who has the authority to act for the trust. (

) Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) research using command code TXMOD with deﬁner A can provide valuable information regarding ATAT in areas such as whipsaw assessments, examination project codes and frivolous ﬁler Indicators, in addition to speciﬁc account transactions and bases. (

) An abusive trust situation occurs when a taxpayer has attempted to reduce eliminate the tax liability through the use of one or more layers of trust When the subjects of the examination refuse to cooperate and the Service unable to accurately determine the correct and agreed tax owed by each entity, the Service will issue whipsaw notices of deﬁciency (for example, one the individual, one to the business trust, and one to the family trust), taxing same income for each entity. (

) When the abusive trust case has defaulted after issuance of the whipsaw statutory notice of deﬁciency due to no agreement received or petition sent the court, a whipsaw assessment will be made. This means that the tax

). Identify the proper person to contact. Because ATAT cases often include multiple entities and whipsaw assessments, care must be given to properly identify the contact person for each entity. Each whipsaw entity should be treated as an individual entity unless the key taxpayer (usually the Individual Master File (IMF) taxpayer) has now reported all income their tax return.

) CKGE provides a graphic representation of a taxpayer’s relationship to other entities. It is not limited to direct investments and can display multiple levels investment tiering. CKEG research may provide a number of beneﬁts on cases because it: a. Expands knowledge of related entities, including investments or tion in entities which may not initially be apparent from other collection activity or research. b. Provides an interactive visual analysis of the taxpayer’s relationships which may be useful in planning the scope of the taxpayer’s cross pliance. c. Provides useful information in conducting a more efficient and effective investigation. (
) Revenue officers can request access to CKGE by submitting an electronic
at: https://ol
enterprise.irs.gov/. The CKGE application name is: “PROD USER CDW GRAPH DATABSE (CDW-UNMASKED TINS).” After ap- proval, users will receive a new account email with login information. (

) Financial Crimes Enforcement Network Query (FCQ) is a web-based applica- tion which is owned by the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (Fi
EN), bureau within the Department of the Treasury. FCQ is a powerful and tool to query and analyze Bank Secrecy Act (BSA) data, which is accessible through the Fi
EN portal. FCQ stores information reported by ﬁnancial tions. (

) The FCQ system provides authorized users with access to currency and BSA reports, such as: • Currency Transaction Report (CTR) • Report of Foreign Bank and Financial Accounts (FBAR) • Designation of Exempt Person • Registration of Money Services Businesses • Report of International Transportation of Currency or Monetary Instru- ments • Report of Cash Payments Over $
Received in a Trade or Business (Form
) • Suspicious Activity Report (SAR) (

) FCQ information is useful in identifying cash activity that may not be reported on the income tax return or disclosed on ﬁnancial statements. FCQ information is a “window” on the underground economy, with invaluable infor- mation not obtainable elsewhere. (
) ATAT, International and GS

) Foreign banking information can be valuable in working ATAT cases and can be utilized as a source to trace a taxpayer’s assets and income. One available to obtain foreign ﬁnancial information is the Treasury Department’s Report of Foreign Bank and Financial Accounts (FBAR), Fi
EN Form
FBAR reports are ﬁled electronically through the BSA e-ﬁling system. (

) FBAR reports must be ﬁled by any United States person who has a ﬁnancial interest in, or signature or other authority over, one or more foreign ﬁnancial accounts that have an aggregate value greater than $

at any time during a calendar year. Failure to ﬁle FBAR reports when required to do so may result in civil and criminal penalties. United States persons include a citizen or resident, a domestic partnership, a domestic limited liability a domestic corporation, and a domestic estate or trust. A “ﬁnancial account” includes, but is not limited to, a securities, brokerage, savings, demand, checking, deposit, time deposit, or other account maintained with a ﬁnancial institution (or other person performing the services of a ﬁnancial institution). ﬁnancial account also includes a commodity futures or options account, an insurance policy with a cash value (such as a whole life insurance policy), annuity policy with a cash value, and shares in a mutual fund or similar fund (i.e., a fund that is available to the general public with a regular net value determination and regular redemptions). (
) Information required on FBAR reports includes: • Number of accounts. • Type of accounts. • Names of ﬁnancial institutions.

Foreign banking information can be valuable in working ATAT cases and can be utilized as a source to trace a taxpayer’s assets and income. One resource available to obtain foreign ﬁnancial information is the Treasury Department’s Report of Foreign Bank and Financial Accounts (FBAR), FinCEN Form 114. FBAR reports are ﬁled electronically through the BSA e-ﬁling system.
5.20.12.10 (05-24-2021) Foreign Bank and Financial
Initial Contact and Research Actions Related to Abusive Tax Avoidance Transactions cases 5.20.12 page 11
page • Last name or organization name of account holder(s). • Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Number. (

) FBAR information may be valuable in working ATAT cases and may be secured through research of IDRS command code IRPTR, and FCQ research. IRPTR research will indicate whether a taxpayer has ﬁled an FBAR report. Once FBAR activity has been noted through command code IRPTR, a officer can access or request FCQ research to obtain transcript data from FBAR ﬁlings. (

) FBAR ﬁlings can provide indicators of offshore activity by a taxpayer. Foreign banking information can be utilized to “follow the money” to trace a taxpayer’s assets and income. FBAR information can also be used to determine if a taxpayer has been forthcoming with ﬁnancial information. Note: Administrative collection action cannot be taken against funds held offshore unless the funds are on deposit in countries with which the U.S. has a col- lection tax treaty, funds are on deposit in an offshore account of a U.S. or the funds are on deposit with an offshore ﬁnancial institution that has a branch in the U.S. or a U.S. territory. See IRM
, Property Outside the United States , for additional information. (
) Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) became law on March

as part of the Hiring Incentives to Restore Employment (HIRE) Act and is intended to improve tax compliance by U.S. taxpayers holding accounts with foreign ﬁnancial institutions or other foreign assets. FATCA increases transpar- ency of offshore accounts through information reporting by foreign ﬁnancial institutions and by certain U.S. taxpayers holding assets outside the United States. Certain U.S. taxpayers holding ﬁnancial assets, including accounts, outside the United States are required to report those assets to the IRS. Foreign ﬁnancial institutions will report to the IRS certain information about ﬁnancial accounts held by U.S. taxpayers, or by foreign entities in which U.S. taxpayers hold a substantial ownership interest. (
) FATCA is a statute written subsequent to the FBAR statute. Under FATCA some taxpayers who ﬁle FBAR reports have a further requirement to ﬁle Form
, Statement of Speciﬁed Foreign Financial Assets, if they have speciﬁed foreign ﬁnancial assets with an aggregate value exceeding $
on the last day of the tax year or $
at any time during the tax year, with higher thresholds for married individuals ﬁling jointly and individuals living abroad. (
) The Form

ﬁling requirement does not replace or otherwise affect a tax- payer’s obligation to ﬁle an FBAR report. Individuals must ﬁle each form for which they meet the relevant reporting threshold. See IRM Exhibit
, Comparison of Form
and FBAR Requirements, for a comparison of two foreign account reporting requirements. (
) IDRS command code RTVUE will indicate that a taxpayer has ﬁled Form The “CC CD” indicator (or Computer Condition Code) will include an “H ” to indicate that Form
was ﬁled. If Form
has been ﬁled, ESTAB the return to view the return information. This may lead to identiﬁcation of a account or asset.
